variant.question:
The following temperatures have been observed over a station at 1200 UTC. 
Assume the station is at MSL. 
Height (ft):  20000   -12°C, 
Height (ft):  18000  -11°C,
Height (ft):  16000  -10°C, 
Height (ft):  14000  -10°C,  
Height (ft):  12000 -6°C, 
Height (ft) 10000 -2°C, 
Height 8000 (ft) : +2°C,
Height (ft):  6000 +6°C, 
Height (ft) : 4000 +12°C, 
Height (ft) 2000 +15°C,
Surface : +15°C 
Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: Assuming that the MSL pressure is 1013.25 hPa the true altitude of an aircraft flying over the station would actually be higher than the indicated altitude.
The layer between 16000 and 18000 ft is absolutely unstable
The temperature at 10000 ft is in agreement with the temperature in the ICAO Standard Atmosphere.
The height of the freezing level over the station is approximately 12000 ft.

at the moment the sun rises.
half an hour before sunrise.
one hour before sunrise.

(1) is incorrect; (2) is correct

variant.question:
What terms/values must be inserted below?

options.text: <div style="list-style-type:none">1. Cumulonimbus; 2. 20
<div style="list-style-type:none">1. Nimbos; 2. 14
1. Cumulonimbus; 2. 12
1. Cumulus; 2. 14

What terms/values must be inserted below?

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the intertropical convergence zone is true?

options.text: There are frequent occurrences of CB
It does not change its position over the oceans during the year
It is an area of low pressure and low relative humidity
It lies totally in the northern hemisphere in July and totally in the southern hemisphere in January

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the intertropical convergence zone is true?

options.text: There are frequent occurrences of CB.
It is an area of low pressure and low relative humidity.
It lies totally in the northern hemisphere in July and totally in the southern hemisphere in January.
It does not change its position over the oceans during the year.

variant.question: Tropical showers and thunderstorms develop in the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ). One of the main reasons for this is the presence of...

options.text: warm, humid, unstable air.

cold air over a warm earth surface.
.
a subsidence inversion in the air.
relatively cold, humid air at low latitudes.

variant.question: Which of the following situations will be typical for the intertropical convergence zone?

options.text: Low pressure and instability.
High pressure the whole year, accompanied by strong prevailing winds.
Hot, mainly dry climate.
High pressure the whole year, accompanied by calm winds.

variant.question: A main condition for the development of tropical showers and thunderstorms in the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ)is the presence of..

options.text: warm, humid, unstable air.
a subsidence inversion in the air.
relatively cold, humid air at low latitudes.
cold air over a warm earth surface.

variant.question: The position of the intertropical convergence zone...

options.text: shows more variation over the continents than over the oceans
shows more variation over the oceans than over the continents
is more to the north in January than in July
depends on the activity of thunderstorm clouds

variant.question: The intertropical convergence zone:

options.text: is characterized by different wind directions on both sides of the zone.
nearly always coincides with the geographical equator.
forms the boundary between tropical and equatorial air.
is always characterized by CB clouds with high tops.

variant.question: In which of the areas below does the intertropical convergence zone (ITCZ) have a significant impact?

options.text: Western Africa between 10°N and 20°N and the northern coasts of the Arabian Sea in July.
The Atlantic Ocean, between latitudes 10°N and 30°N, depending on the time of year.
Western Africa, at a latitude of 25°N in July.
Western Africa, where it is situated between the 10°N and 30°N parallels, during the winter months.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.  
  The typical weather conditions affecting the Darwin area (approx. 12°S / 130°E) during July are:

options.text: dry season - mainly SE winds - visibility reduced by dust and haze.
NW monsoon - very wet - proximity of the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone causes widespread thunderstorm activity.
mainly clear skies - advection fog drifting inland with the typical NE wind.
NE monsoon - continuous heavy rain but little thunderstorm activity.

variant.question: How could a crew visually identify that a tropical squall line is about to pass over their destination aerodrome, and what immediate hazard should they expect on the approach?

options.text: A distinct roll cloud will be followed by a sudden, rapid increase in wind.
A line of Lenticular cloud will be followed by a rapid drop in temperature and sever rime ice.
Cloud will increase rapidly from a Cirrus layer, to Cirrostratus then Altostratus and Nimbostratus, producing rain ice.
A band of Stratocumulus cloud will rapidly lower its base into frontal fog.

variant.question: The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is formed when the northern and southern trade winds converge, thus

options.text: forcing the air up into the atmosphere, generating convective storms, which are short in duration and can be accompanied by intense rainfall.
bringing along with them dry air from the deserts, which mixes with the humid air from the equator, generating unpredictable weather conditions in the tropics.
generating huge storms that slowly progress towards the East, based on the south- and north-easterly direction of the northern and the southern trade wind system.
appearing as a band of clouds, which stays close to the geographic equator of the Earth, as both trade winds are similar in strength.

variant.question: Which set of surface values for temperature/relative humidity and freezing level is typical for the tropical rain climate?

options.text: There are significant yearly variations in rainfall with a wet and a dry period
The annual mean temperature is above 25°C
There are no significant yearly variations in rainfall but there are constant daily variations
Little or no rainfall occurs

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the savannah climate?

options.text: There are significant yearly variations in rainfall with a wet and a dry period.
There are no significant yearly variations in rainfall but there are constant daily variations.
The annual mean temperature is above 25°C.
Little or no rainfall occurs.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the Mediterranean climate?

options.text: The annual rainfall is significantly below 700mm
In winter it is influenced only by the subtropical high pressure belt

options.text: The annual rainfall is significantly below 700 mm.
Hot summers alternate with cold winters.
It is not influenced by the westerlies.

options.text: Frequent and widespread thunderstorms are to be expected within the area of the ITCZ.
Thunderstorms seldom occur within the area of the ITCZ.
The ITCZ is always associated with a strong jet stream.
The ITCZ does not change its position during the course of the year.

variant.question: Which of the following best describes the intertropical convergence zone?

options.text: The zone where the trade winds of the northern hemisphere meet those of the southern hemisphere.
The zone where cold fronts form in the tropics.
The zone where the Harmattan meets the northeasterly trade winds over Africa.
The zone where the west winds meet the subtropical high pressure belt.

variant.question: Which of the following best describes the intertropical convergence zone?

options.text: The zone where the trade winds of the northern hemisphere meet those of the southern hemisphere.
The zone where the Harmattan meets the north-easterly trade winds over Africa.

variant.question: The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is formed when the northern and southern trade winds converge, thus:

options.text: June in southern India to reach Pakistan in July.
December in southern India to reach Pakistan in May.
September in Pakistan to reach southern India in November.
March in southern India to reach Pakistan at the end of April.

variant.question: Where is a squall line most likely to be expected?

options.text: In front of an active cold front.
In front of a cold occlusion at higher levels.
Behind a cold front.
At the surface position of a warm front.

variant.question: What are squall lines?

options.text: Bands of intensive thunderstorms.
Unusual intensive cold fronts.
The surface weather associated with upper air troughs.
The paths of tropical revolving storms.

variant.question: Assuming that an initial "trigger" force is present, the conditions most likely to result in the formation of thunderstorms are:

options.text: high relative humidity and conditional instability throughout a deep layer.
rapid orographic cooling of cloud containing ice crystals.
high surface temperature, low dew point and high dry adiabatic lapse rate.
intense surface heating, anticyclonic pressure system and relatively high freezing level.

variant.question: In addition to the same start conditions as are necessary for an ordinary thunderstorm, a supercell thunderstorm requires...

options.text: very moist air at low level and wind shear that increases with height.
cold, dry air at low level that is overlain by warm, moist air above.
warm, dry air at low level and extremely stable conditions.
cold, moist air at medium level and stable air at high level.

 2. Duration of several months.

 4. Long anvil clouds.

Which of the following sets of conditions are most favourable to the development of thunderstorms?

options.text: Environmental lapse rate greater than saturated adiabatic lapse rate through a great vertical extent, high relative humidity and an initial lifting process.
Extensive isothermal layer, ice particles and water droplets must exist just below the freezing level and orographic lifting.
Environmental lapse rate less than saturated adiabatic lapse rate with dew point below 0°C and considerable surface heating.
Environmental lapse rate less than dry adiabatic lapse rate with freezing level below the cloud base, high relative humidity and strong surface winds.

variant.question: In addition to a lifting action, what are two other requirements necessary for thunderstorm formation?

options.text: Conditional instability and high moisture content
Stable conditions and high moisture content

variant.question: The formation of a thunderstorm occurs if an unstable airmass convects intensely. Hereby parcels of air which are close to the ground rise and form a ___ cloud which is able to grow to a maximum altitude of about ___.

options.text: cumulonimbus; 20 km
cumulus; 14 km
cumulonimbus; 12 km
nimbus; 16 km

options.text: Instability throughout a deep layer extending well above the 0° isotherm.
Stability throughout a deep layer extending well above the 0° isotherm.
ELR less than the DALR extending well above the 0° isotherm.
A marked temperature inversion extending well above the 0° isotherm.
